results.title: Faces
results.brief_description:
Sue Ford’s experimental film “Faces” consists of portraits of the artist and her friends and acquaintances. Ford filmed each subject for roughly 25 seconds, using a wind-up Bolex camera that framed their faces in close-up. Variously self-conscious, serious, amused and distracted, the camera captures every small gesture, expression and flicker of emotion on the person’s face. The result is an examination of portraiture and the performance of identity, demonstrating the artist’s interest in using the camera to capture reality, time and change.

Participants in the film include artists Micky Allan, Bonita Ely and Paul Reed, among others.
results.description:

Variously self-conscious, serious, nonchalant, curious, amused and distracted, the camera captures every small gesture, expression and flicker of emotion on the person’s face. The result is an examination of portraiture and the performance of identity, demonstrating the artist’s interest in using the camera to capture reality, time and change.

Participants in the film include artists Micky Allan, Bonita Ely and Paul Reed, among others.

results.title: Egami
results.creator_credit: Victorian Women's Film Unit and Sue Ford
results.brief_description: In Egami, fashion mannequins are interpreted as women for sale, statues are erected for white men and war, and Melbourne landmarks are totalitarian monuments, in a work that’s exploration of Australian identity and feminism is still relevant today.

constellations_primary.name: Alternate histories and futures
constellations_primary.description: Sue Ford's Egami reimagines contemporary life through a feminist and colonial lens.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Victorian Women’s Film Unit and Sue Ford
results.description: In Sue Ford’s radical short film Egami, Melbourne’s imposing Shrine of Remembrance is rebadged the “New Settlers’ Temple of Wars” by the artist’s intergalactic visitor, who observes from a spaceship. The Shrine is one of many familiar Melbourne landmarks rendered as totalitarian monuments, which have usurped the lands of ‘the Dreaming People’, of which there is no sign left except in Swanston St souvenir stores. In Egami, fashion mannequins are interpreted as women for sale, statues are erected for white men and war, and Hamer Hall is a survival bunker, in a work that’s exploration of Australian identity and feminism is still relevant today.
description_for_label: In Sue Ford’s radical short film Egami, Melbourne’s imposing Shrine of Remembrance is rebadged the “New Settlers’ Temple of Wars” by the artist’s intergalactic visitor, who observes from a spaceship. The Shrine is one of many familiar Melbourne landmarks rendered as totalitarian monuments, which have usurped the lands of ‘the Dreaming People’, of which there is no sign left except in Swanston St souvenir stores. In Egami, fashion mannequins are interpreted as women for sale, statues are erected for white men and war, and Hamer Hall is a survival bunker, in a work that’s exploration of Australian identity and feminism is still relevant today.

results.title: Remembering Uncle Jack Charles
results.material_description: Digital screen recording of a @NITV Tiktok of Uncle Jack Charles' speech accepting the National NAIDOC Male Elder Award in 2022.
results.brief_description:
Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people should be aware that this video contains the name, image and voice of a deceased person.
ACMI mourns the passing of actor, musician and revered Aboriginal Elder, Uncle Jack Charles. The Boon Wurrung, Dja Dja Wurrung, Woiwurrung and Yorta Yorta “father of Black theatre” passed away aged 79.
In addition to his monumental contribution to theatre, film and music, Charles was a survivor of the Stolen Generations, and advocated tirelessly for the rights of incarcerated Indigenous people.
In 2022 he was awarded the National NAIDOC Male Elder Award, giving an acceptance speech that reflects his lifetime of staunch advocacy.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people should be aware that this video contains the name, image and voice of a deceased person.

Revered actor, musician and revered Aboriginal Elder, Uncle Jack Charles has sadly passed aged 79. The Boon Wurrung, Dja Dja Wurrung, Woiwurrung and Yorta Yorta “father of Black theatre” made a monumental contribution to theatre, film and music. He was a survivor of the Stolen Generations and advocated tirelessly for Indigenous rights, reflected in his acceptance speech for the 2022 National NAIDOC Male Elder Award.
description_for_label:
Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people should be aware that this video contains the name, image and voice of a deceased person.

Revered actor, musician and revered Aboriginal Elder, Uncle Jack Charles has sadly passed aged 79. The Boon Wurrung, Dja Dja Wurrung, Woiwurrung and Yorta Yorta “father of Black theatre” made a monumental contribution to theatre, film and music. He was a survivor of the Stolen Generations and advocated tirelessly for Indigenous rights, reflected in his acceptance speech for 2022 the National NAIDOC Male Elder Award.

results.title: A Record of pre-school play
results.creator_credit: State Film Centre of Victoria and Australian Council for Educational Research
results.brief_description: These children are representative of 100 who commenced primary school in Carlton during 1951. Some children had attended the Lady Gowrie Pre-School Centre, some came from other kindergartens and creches and some had not attended any pre-school centre. The children were assembled for two weeks at the end of 1950 to study their vocabulary and this film was made of their unrehearsed and undirected activities. Photography by Rodney Power.

results.title: Free Climbing
results.brief_description: Rock climbing is a recreation for some, an obsession for others. “Free Climbing” was filmed at Mt Arapiles and Mt Buffalo and features hair-raising shots as climbers demonstrate safety and technical skills.

results.title: Fleetwood Mac (this is the one)
results.brief_description: In a year many spent locked inside, Nathan Apodaca gliding down a highway on a skateboard, drinking Ocean Spray and lip-synching Fleetwood Mac’s ‘Dreams’ was the tonic we all needed.

constellations_primary.name: Film and TV dreams
constellations_primary.description: Fleetwood Mac's 'Dreams' coasted its way back up the charts 40 years after it was first released, thanks to Nathan Apodaca's joyous viral TikTok, but Fleetwood Mac (and Stevie Knicks) have been main staples of screen culture for decades.

results.description: In a year many spent locked inside, Nathan Apodaca gliding down a highway on a skateboard, drinking Ocean Spray and lip-synching Fleetwood Mac’s ‘Dreams’ was the tonic we all needed. The 22-second viral video sparked countless imitations, with the band’s drummer and co-founder, Mick Fleetwood, even recreating the carefree moment. He also cashed in on the iconic TikTok video, which was viewed more than 50 million times and coasted ‘Dreams’ back into the charts. Capturing the mood of a tumultuous year, Apodaca’s wholesome performance gave the world some long overdue joy.
description_for_label: In a year many spent locked inside, Nathan Apodaca gliding down a highway on a skateboard, drinking Ocean Spray and lip-synching Fleetwood Mac’s ‘Dreams’ was the tonic we all needed. The 22-second viral video sparked countless imitations, with the band’s drummer and co-founder, Mick Fleetwood, even recreating the carefree moment. He also cashed in on the iconic TikTok video, which was viewed more than 50 million times and coasted ‘Dreams’ back into the charts. Capturing the mood of a tumultuous year, Apodaca’s wholesome performance gave the world some long overdue joy.

results.title: Another day, another Emmanuel don’t do it
results.brief_description: TikTok’s newest cute animal to become a viral sensation is an attention-seeking emu named Emmanuel from @KnuckleBumpFarms, a small hobby farm in Florida. Emmanuel’s most famous antics involve disrupting his owner, the influencer Taylor Blake, as she attempts to film content for her 2M followers. Blake runs the farm with her girlfriend Kristian Haggerty, who was previously one half of the first LGBT+ couple to appear on reality show The Bachelor in Paradise.
results.title_for_label: Another day, another Emmanuel don’t do it
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

TikTok’s newest cute animal to become a viral sensation is an attention-seeking emu named Emmanuel from @KnuckleBumpFarms, a small hobby farm in Florida. Emmanuel’s most famous antics involve disrupting his owner, the influencer Taylor Blake, as she attempts to film content for her 2M followers. Blake runs the farm with her girlfriend Kristian Haggerty, who was previously one half of the first LGBT+ couple to appear on reality show The Bachelor in Paradise.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Minds → MM-09. Catch of the Day

results.title: Free shadow movies
results.brief_description: Like a filmic haiku, this very short film is a series of observations of the ‘free shadow movies’ that play on the streets of everyday life. Gathering images of light, time and motion from the most simple moments - a passing train, children playing - the filmmaker has created an immersion into urban mysteries of shadow and sensation. The result, while simple and modest, is a hypnotic perception of street life as glimpsed from the corners of the eye.

results.title: Pierre et Paul = Pierre and Paul
results.creator_credit: Rene Allio, Yves Robert and Leon Carre
results.brief_description:
Pierre, a middle manager in a building company, decides to buy a appartment and live with his girlfriend, Martine. But, the subsequent death of his father and various financial difficulties soon damage his mental equilibrium. When the May ‘68 riots errupt, Pierre goes off the rails.

Credits: Producer, Leon Carre, Yves Robert ; director, Rene Allio ; writer, Rene Allio ; photography, Georges Leclerc ; music, Jacques Dutronc.
Cast: Pierre Mondy, Robert Juillard, Bulle Ogier, Madeleine Barbulee, Helene Vincent.

results.title: Bare
results.creator_credit: Amanda Roberts, Wild Iris Productions, Liz Baulch and Deborah Strutt
results.brief_description: There are misunderstandings aplenty in this award-winning Australian short when 2 gay boys accidentally catch their lesbian neighbours in an early morning clinch. High density living in all its revealing glory.
